Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Gloryman that's an extremely difficult thing to do in decentralized mining, in some ways impossible. pools are independent and can mine according to the protocol the way they want. if they limit hash rate, big miners would go elsewhere. the network mining is only based on addresses and submissions that win. you can't really know for sure how much hash rate anyone has. you can only calculate individual or network hashrate, and the pools of course, can count shares, which mean nothing to the network.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @miketout ok never mind. I thought I was being clever.😂 Anyway, really nice announcements mike I'm really looking forward to verus has 2.0

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @dude personally, I'm not afraid of FPGA miners. I was even arguing to cooperate and work with the FPGA company as we level the playing field, so that FPGAs are still the most professional option, but that CPUs and GPUs are reasonable for casual mining. It might seem surprising, but we really do believe in decentralized mining. We hope that PBaaS will also encourage more decentralized mining and make mining Verus more profitable as well. The more decentralized the network is, the more it will scale, and because of that, there will be a place for even casual miners, if FPGAs don't knock them all out now. We got to a point in discussions where we realized that the sticking point we were trying to secure for the community was that we would have assurance that if we said someone should buy the miners that they would still work after the fork, and it would not be a mistake for the buyer. The company really may not have been trying to be difficult, but they felt they needed to see the full algorithm before release, and we wanted to give them a sense for it with enough information for an FPGA dev to know if they could do it, then get assurance that they would. We realized that if we give them the algo and get no assurance, we would be here, but we would have given the algo that might help the community have a chance to catch up a little while the whole FPGA thing restarts with all of us having the experience of learning from this round. I think for the hardware companies, they need to think about who are their primary customers and how many they will sell.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> For us, we need to think about more decentralization through equalization while not fighting progress.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> If the primary customer of FPGA miners are people who want to snipe coins in secret for maximum ROI, i believe that will remain a small group that actually is self defeating. They harm the coins they snipe, drive the value down, and lose their ROI if the company sells enough to saturate the immediate profit of sniping.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> If the customer is coin communities wanting to do much better on their coin, but not centralize everything, then they either need to think super high volume for explicitly the miner market, which i think is coming, or serve growing communities with the best miner that still can coexist with others

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> we cannot always have everything equal. fair to me is generally you put more in, you get more out in a fair measure. i don't think that is the part that would drive a desire to equalize hardware because fair just means everyone can technically do the same thing with the same resources. that wouldn't preclude all FPGA in my opinion, but that would be centralizing. the reason to equalize in a reasonable way if it can be done, IMO, is to get more decentralization and a growing network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i believe that if someone is willing to spend explicitly on mining crypto currency, which is what they're doing with an FPGA today, they should get a premium ROI for that commitment

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Sweet. I completely agree. With more casual miners, that means we can expand and help the community build. Also, were you talking about the new RTX cards with tensor cores? I was wondering what kind of performance boost they could provide.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but i also believe that people should reasonably be able to get an ROI on common hardware, which should translate into profit in a better market

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <GEBucky> OK  - been watching this all unfold. There is no "secret society". As a loyal and committed GPU miner, I also have FPGA's. The effect on Verus does concern me. That said - not a secret hidden group of "secret miners" - it is called innovation and the fact of the matter is FPGA is really efficient. And when people innovate on new tech they don't just "put it out there to share". It's brutal and hard fact of POW. All mining is about staying one step ahead, not trying to hurt individual and great projects. But the straight up facts are ... FPGAs are here. Many different companies and devs are in a race to develop efficient algorithms. It's evolution or we would be all mining on our palm pilots in the back of a horse buggy. So yes - it sucks. Fully get that. But you simply have to embrace it and adopt. Fork, modify, whatever. But no secret society out to get you - just folks with fast hardware that smokes GPU on this algorithm. Crypto won't survive if people blame innovation for distributing their calm peaceful world. Everything is disruption right now. I am holding a big chunk of Verus as love the passion and the project. But hating the FPGA folks is just crazy and misguided - it's here, it real, and it's not "a company" or "centralized party" coming after you. I am going to hate myself for posting this but come on - stop blaming some centralized evil system and just realize that tech innovation caught you off guard and you will need to adapt. How far behind do you think ASICS would be. Don't negotiate a peace treaty - INNOVATE.
